subject: Re: [junit] junit on large scale
msgSnippet: ... It seems to me little effort at all to create an appropriate MockBigObject, if you set up your system right. Let s say your doSomething looks like this:
messageBody:
On Wed, 2 Jun 2004, Mike Clark wrote:

> Say we have a method that takes a BigObject and does something with a
> subset of the data in that object:
>
> public void doSomething(BigObject o) {
> String s = o.getStringValue();
> int i = o.getIntValue();
> // do something with 's' and 'i'
> }
>
> There are several other methods like doSomething() in the system, so
> the initial reaction is to mock BigObject so that we can pass it into
> doSomething() and the other methods. BigObject has a lot of setup
> involved to put it into a test state, but with some effort we can
> create a MockBigObject.

It seems to me little effort at all to create an appropriate
MockBigObject, if you set up your system right. Let's say your
doSomething looks like this:

public void doSomething(BigObject biggie) {
String s = biggie.getStringValue();
int i = biggie.getIntValue();
if (s == null && i == 0)
biggie.setResult(true);
else
biggie.setResult(false);
}

Test it with:

BigObject mock = new BigObject() {
public String getStringValue() {
return null;
}
public int getIntValue() {
return 0;
}
public void setResult(boolean result) {
assertTrue(result);
}
}
objectUnderTest.doSomething(mock);

(Of course, if this were a real program, you probably have a method
that looks like this unless it was doing something else important
outside of BigObject, that you'd also be testing.)

The secret to mocking, IMHO, is to make mocks that do the bare minimum
necessary to test the functionality in question, rather than trying to
make ones that actually look or act anything like the real object.
